facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 988 and 989 of 1964 are appeals from the judgment and decree dated February 16, 1961 of the Patna High Court in Appeal from Original Decree No. 390 of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 988 and 989 of 1964. Appeals from the judgment and decree dated February 16, 1961 of the Patna High Court in Appeal from Original Decree No. 390 of 1953.

facts.text: One Harbans Narain Singh was the proprietor of villages Seha and Dhobaha and other villages.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Bachawat, J. One Harbans Narain Singh was the proprietor of villages Seha and Dhobaha and other villages.

facts.text: Harbans Narain created a mortgage dated February 10, 1886 in favour of Basanti Bibi over these villages.

anchor.surface_text: He created several encumbrances over these villages including a mortgage dated February 10, 1886 in favour of Basanti Bibi, two mortgages dated September 9, 1907 and February 5, 1910,

facts.text: Harbans Narain created two mortgages dated September 9, 1907 and February 5, 1910, in favour of Harprasad Das over these villages.

anchor.surface_text: He created several encumbrances over these villages including a mortgage dated February 10, 1886 in favour of Basanti Bibi, two mortgages dated September 9, 1907 and February 5, 1910, in favour of Harprasad Das

facts.text: Harbans Narain created a mortgage dated August 2, 1911 in favour of defendant No. 1 Ramanandan Lal over these villages.

facts.text: On June 23, 1915, Harbans Narain sold the villages to Mahabir Missir subject to the above mortgages.

facts.text: Mahabir Missir redeemed the mortgages in favour of Basanti Bibi and Harprasad Das and became subrogated to their rights.

facts.text: Ramanandan Lal instituted a suit to enforce his mortgage, obtained a final decree for sale, put the decree into execution, purchased villages Seha and Dhobaha at execution sale and obtained possession in 1919 and 1920.

anchor.surface_text: Ramanandan Lal instituted a suit to enforce his mortgage, obtained a final decree for sale, put the decree into execution, at the execution sale purchased villages Seha and Dhobaha and obtained possession of the villages in 1919 and 1920.

facts.text: In 1924, Mahabir instituted suit No. 17 of 1924 to enforce his mortgage lien praying for ratable contribution of his dues in respect of villages Seha and Dhobaha from Ramanandan Lal and obtained a final decree on August 22, 1931.

anchor.surface_text: In 1924, Mahabir instituted suit No. 17 of 1924 to enforce his mortgage lien praying for ratable companytribution of his dues in respect of villages Seha and Dhobaha from Ramanandan Lal and obtained a final decree on August 22, 1931.

facts.text: Mahabir died leaving his son Kashinath as his legal representative.

anchor.surface_text: Mahabir died leaving his son Kashinath as his legal representative. Kashinath put the decree in suit No. 17 of 1924 into execution.

facts.text: On July 13, 1934, Ramanandan Lal paid the decreetal dues in respect of village Seha.

facts.text: On November 4, 1935, village Dhobaha was sold in execution of the decree in suit No. 17 of 1924 and was purchased by Kashinath.

facts.text: In June, 1934, Ramanandan Lal through his constituted attorney, Munshi Sheobaran Lal granted five leases in respect of the suit lands in the village to defendants 2 to 7.

facts.text: The subordinate Judge, Arrah, held that the leases were genuine, were granted by Ramanandan Lal in due course of management and were binding on the plaintiffs and dismissed the suit.

holdings.text: The contention that the adverse orders passed against Kashinath in the proceedings under O. 21, r. 58, CPC operated as res judicata and precluded him and the deity from alleging that the leases were not binding on them should be rejected.

anchor.surface_text: We think that this contention should be rejected. In view of the orders passed against Kashinath in the claim proceedings and his failure to institute suits under O. 21, r. 63, CPC, Kashinath was precluded from claiming that he had the right to attach the suit lands in execution of his money decree, but he was not precluded from claiming that he had the right to sell the lands in execution of his mortgage decree.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Claim proceeding under r.58 not a suit; order conclusive only via r.63 on liability to attachment/sale in that specific execution; not res judicata independently or beyond that decree; distinguished Subbier and Sarju Prasad as limited to same execution.

holdings.text: A claim proceeding under r. 58 is not a suit or a proceeding analogous to a suit. An order in the claim proceeding does not operate as res judicata. It is because of rule 63 that the order becomes conclusive.

anchor.surface_text: A claim proceeding under r. 58 is not a suit or a proceeding analogous to a suit. An order in the claim proceeding does not operate as res judicata. It is because of rule 63 that the order becomes conclusive. The effect of r. 63 is that unless a suit is brought as provided by the rule,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explicit textual reading of rr.58-63; conclusiveness limited to re-agitation of attachment/sale liability in that decree's execution only.

holdings.text: Section 65A of the Transfer of Property Act did not affect the incidents of the mortgages executed before April 1, 1930, including the mortgagor's power to grant leases binding on the mortgagee.

anchor.surface_text: Section 65A was inserted in the Transfer of Property Act, 1882 by s. 30 of the Transfer of Property Amendment Act, 1929, which came into force on April 1, 1930 Section 63 of the Transfer of Property Amendment Act 1929 provided that nothing in the provisions of s. 30

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.63 of 1929 Amending Act expressly saves terms/incidents of pre-1930 mortgages; leasing power is such incident unaffected by new s.65A.

holdings.text: The leases granted by Ramanandan Lal were not in the ordinary course of management of the mortgagor as the agent or bailiff of the mortgagee, and were not binding on the mortgagee.

anchor.surface_text: the question whether the mortgagor in possession has power to lease the mortgaged property must be determined with reference to the authority of the mortgagor as the bailiff or agent for the mortgagee to deal with the property in the usual course of management.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Leases permanent with fixed rent perpetuity, nazrana/premium, post-sale advertisement, in bad faith to defeat decree-holder; exceed agent authority; applying pre-s65A law per precedents Madan Mohan Singh, Raja Kamakshya Narayan Singh, Gobinda Chandra Saha.

holdings.text: All the leases were created after the property was advertised for sale in execution of the mortgage decree. The leases were created by the mortgagor in bad faith with a view to cause loss to the mortgagee-decree-holder.

anchor.surface_text: All the leases were created after the property was advertised for sale in execution of the mortgage decree. The High Court has found that the leases were created by the mortgagor in bad faith with a view to cause loss

holdings.reasoning_summary: Accepting High Court fact findings on timing and intent; not ordinary management.

holdings.text: An auction-purchaser at a sale held in execution of a mortgage decree buys not only the interest of the mortgagor but also the interest of the mortgagee. If the lease does not bind the mortgagee, it does not equally bind the auction-purchaser.

anchor.surface_text: An auction-purchaser at a sale held in execution of a mortgage decree buys not only the interest of the mortgagor but also the interest of the mortgagee. If the lease does not bind the mortgagee, it does not equally bind the auction-purchaser.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Purchaser steps into mortgagee's shoes regarding lease bindingness; analogous to Rust v Goodale.

holdings.text: We do not think it necessary to decide [whether the leases were sham transactions]. Even assuming that the leases were not sham transactions they were not binding on Kashinath and the deity.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that the leases were sham transactions. We do not think it necessary to decide this question. Even assuming that the leases were not sham transactions they were not binding on Kashinath and the deity.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Unnecessary as leases invalid on independent grounds of not ordinary management.

holdings.text: The High Court rightly decreed the suit. The appeals are dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court rightly decreed the suit. The appeals are dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: An auction-purchaser at a sale held in execution of a mortgage decree buys not only the interest of the mortgagor but also the interest of the mortgagee. If the lease does not bind the mortgagee, it does not equally bind the auction-purchaser.
